10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-008-9360-8936010.1007/s10870-008-9360-8Original PaperCrystal of Tetrakis(1-ethyl-1H-imidazole)diisothiocyanatocopper(II) bis(1-ethyl-1H-imidazole)diisothiocyanatocopper(II)LiuGuang Ye12aChenHong Na2LiuFa Qian2HuangSu Yi1LiShao Xiang2LiWei2grid.33199.310000000403687223Institute of Energy and PowerHuazhong University of Science and Technology430074WuhanPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.412610.00000000122297077Key Laboratory of Advanced MaterialsQingdao University of Science and Technology266042QingdaoPeople’s Republic of Chinaqdlgy2008@sina.com2942008820083886316342732008712200627320082942008© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20082008Abstract

A new complex [Cu(NCS)4 (N-Eim)4] [Cu(NCS)2 (N-Eim)2] (where N-Eim = N-ethylimidazole) has been synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The compound crystallizes in the Triclinic space group P−1 with the parameters: a = 8.7707(18) Å, b = 10.712(2) Å, c = 13.511(3) Å, α = 104.73(3)°, β = 104.84(3)°, γ = 102.52(3)°, V = 1131.54(3) Å3, with Z = 1 formula units. In the structure, the copper atoms all assume an elongated octahedral geometry with two distinct coordination environments; one is coordinated by four N-ethyl-imidazole ligands and two axial SCN groups, and another by two SCN groups and two N-ethyl-imidazole ligands. The two units form one infinite 1D zigzag chain along the [1 0 1] plane by two thiocyanate ligands from the [Cu(NCS)4 (N-Eim)4] units.

Index Abstract

The title compound, tetrakis(1-ethyl-1H-imidazole)diisothio cyanatocopper(II) bis(1-ethyl-1H-imidazole)diisothiocyanatocopper(II) has been synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In the structure, the copper atoms all assume an elongated octahedral geometry with two distinct coordination environments. The two units form one infinite 1D zigzag chain along the [1 0 1] plane by two thiocyanate ligands from the [Cu(NCS)4 (N-Eim) 4] units.

KeywordsCopper (II) complexesThiocyanato complexesCrystal structuresvolume-issue-count12issue-article-count15issue-toc-levels0issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2008article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2008article-registration-date-month3article-registration-date-day27article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10870_2008_Article_9360.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2008issue-online-date-month7issue-online-date-day8issue-print-date-year2008issue-print-date-month7issue-print-date-day8issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryCrystallography journal-subject-secondaryOrganometallic Chemistry open-accessfalseIntroduction

Imidazole is of considerable interest as a ligand in many biological systems in which it provides a potential binding site for metal ions [1]. It has been reported that a large number of imidazole derivatives possess diverse pharmacological effects, including anti-inflammatory, antimalarial and antitumor activities [2, 3]. Furthermore, the isothiocyanato anion is a versatile inorganic ligand in the synthesis of coordinated compounds. In this paper we investigate the influence of steric properties [4] on stoichiometry and report the crystal structure of the title compound (I), an imidazole derivative of a thiocyanate-containing copper (II) complex that is related to similar structures that we have recently synthesized [5, 6].

ExperimentalSynthesis

The title compound was prepared by the reaction of 1-ethylimidazole (1.44 g, 15 mmol) with CuCl2 · 2H2O (0.85 g, 5 mmol) and potassium thiocyanate (0.98 g, 10 mmol) by means of hydrothermal synthesis in a Teflon lined stainless-steel reactor at 383 K for 24 h. Single crystals suitable for X-ray measurements were obtained by recrystallization from methanol at room temperature.

Structural Determination

The selected crystal with approximate dimensions of 0.35 mm × 0.25 mm × 0.25 mm was mounted on a glass fiber. The data were collected on an Enraf-Nonius CAD4 diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.071073 nm) radiation at a temperature of 293(2) K, using an ω-2θ scan mode (1.65° < θ < 25.96°). Intensities were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects, empirical absorption, and data reduction using the SADABS [7] program.

The structure was solved by the direct methods using SHELXS-97 [8]. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined on F2 anistropically by full-matrix least squares method. All hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions assigned fixed isotropic thermal parameters at 1.2 times the equivalent isotropic U of the atoms to which they are attached and allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms. The contributions of these hydrogen atoms were included in structure-factor calculations. The total reflections were 4359 and the final cycle of full-matrix least-squares refinement was based on 4655 observed reflections (R(int) = 0.0282). The final least-square cycle gave R1 = 0.0613, wR2 = 0.1576 for 3007 observed reflections with I > 2σ (I); the weighting scheme, w = 1/[σ2(Fo2) + (0.1191P)2], where P = (Fo2 + 2Fc2)/3, the maximum shift (Δ/σ)max = 0.000 and S = 1.046. The maximum and minimum peaks on the final difference Fourier map corresponded to 0.858e Å−3 and −0.891e Å−3, respectively. Atomic scattering factors and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Table for X-ray Crystallography [9]. Crystal and refinement data for the title complex are listed in Table 1.

Result and Discussion

Figure 1 shows the structure of the title compound with 50% probability displacement ellipsoids and the atom-numbering scheme. Figure 2 shows the crystal packing viewed along the a axis of the unit cell, weak Cu–S bonds are drawn in dashed lines. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are presented in Table 2.

The crystal structure of the title compound consists of distinct [Cu(NCS)4 · (N-Eim)4] and [Cu(NCS)2 · (N-Eim)2] units which form one infinite 1D zigzag chain along the [1 0 1] plane by two thiocyanate ligands from the [Cu(NCS)4 · (N-Eim)4] units. In the [Cu(NCS)4 · (N-Eim)4] unit, the Cu atom lies on a mirror plan and adopts a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry, with six N atoms from two thiocyanate anions and four 1-ethylimidazole ligands. The equatorial plane of the complex is formed by four Cu–N(1-ethylimadazole) bonds [Cu–N3 = 2.040(4) and Cu–N5 = 2.012(4) Å], and the axial positions are occupied by two N-bonded NCS groups [Cu–N1 = 2.453(5) Å]. Due to the existence of a weak S1–Cu2 bond, the Cu–N1 distance is longer than the Cu–N(NCS) distances in [Cu(bimtp)(NCS)2]bimtp (2.004(5) and 1.994(5) Å, bimtp = 1,5-bis(4-imidazolyl)-3-thiapentane] [10], [Cu(Mim)(NCS)2]Mim (2.013(2) Å; Mim = methylimidazole) [11] and [Cu(im)2(NCS)2]im (1.975(2) Å; im = imidazole) [12]. The CuN6 geometry in the title compound is only slightly distorted from octahedral geometry. The trans angles are all approximately 180° and the cis angles differ slightly from 90°. The largest octahedral distorted occurs with the N3–Cu1–N5 angle, which differs from 90° by 2.05(17)°. In the [Cu(NCS)2 · (N-Eim)2] unit, the Cu atom lies on a mirror plane and adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The equatorial plane is occupied by four nitrogen atoms from two exobidentate Eim groups and two thiocyanate groups coordinated in a symmetric end-to-end fashion via two nitrogen atoms. The Cu–N2 and Cu–N7 distances are 1.971(5) and 2.003(4) Å, respectively, which are similar to those in complex [Cu(im)2(NCS)2] [12]. The two bridging sulfur atoms from the bidentate thiocyanate ligands are weakly coordinated to the Cu2 atom in the axial position. The Cu–S bond distance (3.055(15) Å) is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu and S atoms (3.4 Å) and also shorter than that in [Cu(im)2(NCS)2] [12]. The thiocyanate group is close to linear in both units with the N–C–S angle of 178.1(5)° for [Cu(NCS)4 · (N-Eim)4] 12] and 178.7(5)° for [Cu(NCS)2 · (N-Eim)2] [12].

In the title compound, the polymer backbone propagates along the [1 0 1] plane. The metal-metal distances across each polymer backbone are 7.049(2) Å, whereas the closest metal-metal distances between neighboring strands are 8.771(2) Å.

Acknowledgements

This project was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant No. 20601015).

Abstract

A new complex [Cu(NCS)4 (N-Eim)4] [Cu(NCS)2 (N-Eim)2] (where N-Eim = N-ethylimidazole) has been synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The compound crystallizes in the Triclinic space group P-1 with the parameters: a = 8.7707(18) Å, b = 10.712(2) Å, c = 13.511(3) Å, α = 104.73(3)°, β = 104.84(3)°, γ = 102.52(3)°, V = 1131.54(3) Å3, with Z = 1 formula units. In the structure, the copper atoms all assume an elongated octahedral geometry with two distinct coordination environments; one is coordinated by four N-ethyl-imidazole ligands and two axial SCN groups, and another by two SCN groups and two N-ethyl-imidazole ligands. The two units form one infinite 1D zigzag chain along the [1 0 1] plane by two thiocyanate ligands from the [Cu(NCS)4 (N-Eim)4] units.

In the structure, the copper atoms all assume an elongated octahedral geometry with two distinct coordination environments. The two units form one infinite 1D zigzag chain along the [1 0 1] plane by two thiocyanate ligands from the [Cu(NCS)4 (N-Eim) 4] units.

The selected crystal with approximate dimensions of 0.35 mm × 0.25 mm × 0.25 mm was mounted on a glass fiber. The data were collected on an Enraf-Nonius CAD4 diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.071073 nm) radiation at a temperature of 293(2) K, using an ω-2θ scan mode (1.65° < θ < 25.96°). Intensities were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects, empirical absorption, and data reduction using the SADABS [7] program.

elements.content: The structure was solved by the direct methods using SHELXS-97 [8]. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined on F2 anistropically by full-matrix least squares method. All hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions assigned fixed isotropic thermal parameters at 1.2 times the equivalent isotropic U of the atoms to which they are attached and allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms. The contributions of these hydrogen atoms were included in structure-factor calculations. The total reflections were 4359 and the final cycle of full-matrix least-squares refinement was based on 4655 observed reflections (R(int) = 0.0282). The final least-square cycle gave R1 = 0.0613, wR2 = 0.1576 for 3007 observed reflections with I > 2σ (I); the weighting scheme, w = 1/[σ2(Fo2) + (0.1191P)2], where P = (Fo2 + 2Fc2)/3, the maximum shift (Δ/σ)max = 0.000 and S = 1.046. The maximum and minimum peaks on the final difference Fourier map corresponded to 0.858e Å−3 and −0.891e Å−3, respectively. Atomic scattering factors and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Table for X-ray Crystallography [9]. Crystal and refinement data for the title complex are listed in Table 1.
elements.clean_text: The structure was solved by the direct methods using SHELXS-97 [8]. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined on F2 anistropically by full-matrix least squares method. All hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions assigned fixed isotropic thermal parameters at 1.2 times the equivalent isotropic U of the atoms to which they are attached and allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms. The contributions of these hydrogen atoms were included in structure-factor calculations. The total reflections were 4359 and the final cycle of full-matrix least-squares refinement was based on 4655 observed reflections (R(int) = 0.0282). The final least-square cycle gave R1 = 0.0613, wR2 = 0.1576 for 3007 observed reflections with I > 2σ (I); the weighting scheme, w = 1/[σ2(Fo2) + (0.1191P)2], where P = (Fo2 + 2Fc2)/3, the maximum shift (Δ/σ)max = 0.000 and S = 1.046. The maximum and minimum peaks on the final difference Fourier map corresponded to 0.858e Å-3 and -0.891e Å-3, respectively. Atomic scattering factors and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Table for X-ray Crystallography [9]. Crystal and refinement data for the title complex are listed in Table 1.

Figure 1 shows the structure of the title compound with 50% probability displacement ellipsoids and the atom-numbering scheme. Figure 2 shows the crystal packing viewed along the a axis of the unit cell, weak Cu–S bonds are drawn in dashed lines. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are presented in Table 2.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

Figure 1 shows the structure of the title compound with 50% probability displacement ellipsoids and the atom-numbering scheme. Figure 2 shows the crystal packing viewed along the a axis of the unit cell, weak Cu-S bonds are drawn in dashed lines. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are presented in Table 2.

Note: Symmetry codes: a −x,−y + 2,−z + 2 b −x + 1,−y + 2,−z + 3

The crystal structure of the title compound consists of distinct [Cu(NCS)4 · (N-Eim)4] and [Cu(NCS)2 · (N-Eim)2] units which form one infinite 1D zigzag chain along the [1 0 1] plane by two thiocyanate ligands from the [Cu(NCS)4 · (N-Eim)4] units. In the [Cu(NCS)4 · (N-Eim)4] unit, the Cu atom lies on a mirror plan and adopts a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry, with six N atoms from two thiocyanate anions and four 1-ethylimidazole ligands. The equatorial plane of the complex is formed by four Cu–N(1-ethylimadazole) bonds [Cu–N3 = 2.040(4) and Cu–N5 = 2.012(4) Å], and the axial positions are occupied by two N-bonded NCS groups [Cu–N1 = 2.453(5) Å]. Due to the existence of a weak S1–Cu2 bond, the Cu–N1 distance is longer than the Cu–N(NCS) distances in [Cu(bimtp)(NCS)2]bimtp (2.004(5) and 1.994(5) Å, bimtp = 1,5-bis(4-imidazolyl)-3-thiapentane] [10], [Cu(Mim)(NCS)2]Mim (2.013(2) Å; Mim = methylimidazole) [11] and [Cu(im)2(NCS)2]im (1.975(2) Å; im = imidazole) [12]. The CuN6 geometry in the title compound is only slightly distorted from octahedral geometry. The trans angles are all approximately 180° and the cis angles differ slightly from 90°. The largest octahedral distorted occurs with the N3–Cu1–N5 angle, which differs from 90° by 2.05(17)°. In the [Cu(NCS)2 · (N-Eim)2] unit, the Cu atom lies on a mirror plane and adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The equatorial plane is occupied by four nitrogen atoms from two exobidentate Eim groups and two thiocyanate groups coordinated in a symmetric end-to-end fashion via two nitrogen atoms. The Cu–N2 and Cu–N7 distances are 1.971(5) and 2.003(4) Å, respectively, which are similar to those in complex [Cu(im)2(NCS)2] [12]. The two bridging sulfur atoms from the bidentate thiocyanate ligands are weakly coordinated to the Cu2 atom in the axial position. The Cu–S bond distance (3.055(15) Å) is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu and S atoms (3.4 Å) and also shorter than that in [Cu(im)2(NCS)2] [12]. The thiocyanate group is close to linear in both units with the N–C–S angle of 178.1(5)° for [Cu(NCS)4 · (N-Eim)4] 12] and 178.7(5)° for [Cu(NCS)2 · (N-Eim)2] [12].
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of the title compound consists of distinct [Cu(NCS)4 ⋅ (N-Eim)4] and [Cu(NCS)2 ⋅ (N-Eim)2] units which form one infinite 1D zigzag chain along the [1 0 1] plane by two thiocyanate ligands from the [Cu(NCS)4 ⋅ (N-Eim)4] units. In the [Cu(NCS)4 ⋅ (N-Eim)4] unit, the Cu atom lies on a mirror plan and adopts a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry, with six N atoms from two thiocyanate anions and four 1-ethylimidazole ligands. The equatorial plane of the complex is formed by four Cu-N(1-ethylimadazole) bonds [Cu-N3 = 2.040(4) and Cu-N5 = 2.012(4) Å], and the axial positions are occupied by two N-bonded NCS groups [Cu-N1 = 2.453(5) Å]. Due to the existence of a weak S1-Cu2 bond, the Cu-N1 distance is longer than the Cu-N(NCS) distances in [Cu(bimtp)(NCS)2]bimtp (2.004(5) and 1.994(5) Å, bimtp = 1,5-bis(4-imidazolyl)-3-thiapentane] [10], [Cu(Mim)(NCS)2]Mim (2.013(2) Å; Mim = methylimidazole) [11] and [Cu(im)2(NCS)2]im (1.975(2) Å; im = imidazole) [12]. The CuN6 geometry in the title compound is only slightly distorted from octahedral geometry. The trans angles are all approximately 180° and the cis angles differ slightly from 90°. The largest octahedral distorted occurs with the N3-Cu1-N5 angle, which differs from 90° by 2.05(17)°. In the [Cu(NCS)2 ⋅ (N-Eim)2] unit, the Cu atom lies on a mirror plane and adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The equatorial plane is occupied by four nitrogen atoms from two exobidentate Eim groups and two thiocyanate groups coordinated in a symmetric end-to-end fashion via two nitrogen atoms. The Cu-N2 and Cu-N7 distances are 1.971(5) and 2.003(4) Å, respectively, which are similar to those in complex [Cu(im)2(NCS)2] [12]. The two bridging sulfur atoms from the bidentate thiocyanate ligands are weakly coordinated to the Cu2 atom in the axial position. The Cu-S bond distance (3.055(15) Å) is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu and S atoms (3.4 Å) and also shorter than that in [Cu(im)2(NCS)2] [12]. The thiocyanate group is close to linear in both units with the N-C-S angle of 178.1(5)° for [Cu(NCS)4 ⋅ (N-Eim)4] 12] and 178.7(5)° for [Cu(NCS)2 ⋅ (N-Eim)2] [12].

elements.content: In the title compound, the polymer backbone propagates along the [1 0 1] plane. The metal-metal distances across each polymer backbone are 7.049(2) Å, whereas the closest metal-metal distances between neighboring strands are 8.771(2) Å.
elements.clean_text: In the title compound, the polymer backbone propagates along the [1 0 1] plane. The metal-metal distances across each polymer backbone are 7.049(2) Å, whereas the closest metal-metal distances between neighboring strands are 8.771(2) Å.

cln_elements.content: The title compound was prepared by the reaction of 1-ethylimidazole (1.44 g, 15 mmol) with CuCl2 · 2H2O (0.85 g, 5 mmol) and potassium thiocyanate (0.98 g, 10 mmol) by means of hydrothermal synthesis in a Teflon lined stainless-steel reactor at 383 K for 24 h. Single crystals suitable for X-ray measurements were obtained by recrystallization from methanol at room temperature.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis

The title compound was prepared by the reaction of 1-ethylimidazole (1.44 g, 15 mmol) with CuCl2 ⋅ 2H2O (0.85 g, 5 mmol) and potassium thiocyanate (0.98 g, 10 mmol) by means of hydrothermal synthesis in a Teflon lined stainless-steel reactor at 383 K for 24 h. Single crystals suitable for X-ray measurements were obtained by recrystallization from methanol at room temperature.
